title: A tessera hospitalis recording xenia between Imulch and Lyson
support: An ivory token carved on one long side in the form of  two clasped left hands, and cut vertically smooth on the reverse, on which face are four lines of Greek letters. A crack runs diagonally across the upper left corner of the reverse, and a fragment is lost from the upper edge of the middle of the rear (inscribed) face. Slight damage to the lower corners.

layout.p: Four lines of Greek letters, with a consistent left margin, starting at the top of the rear (smooth) side of the tessera, with small vacat below.

handNote.lettering: Small, slightly irregular letters without serifs. Lunate epsilon, sigma and omega; mu formed by four, equal slanting strokes; omicron generally slightly smaller than other letters; beta is closed, but with separated loops; rho is closed; xsi in form of a Z with horizontal cross bar; kappa has short equal length arms.

date._: 2nd century BCE, or possibly 1st century BCE (the letter forms look more plausibly second than 1st century)

provenanceFound._: Found 'nel fondo del conte Antonio Grignano' (Salinas 1873: 53 n.2) in the vicinity of Marsala, in 1749; it was acquired by the museum of the Benedictine monastery of S. Martino, whence it passed to the Palermo Museo archeologico regionale, and subsequently to the Marsala museo archeologico regionale, where currently on display.

repository._: Museo archeologico regionale Lilibeo Marsala - Baglio Anselmi
